rooms.description:
You're working on A2 for your favorite class, CS 3110, when you find yourself
completely lost and confused about functional programming! (How you made it
through A1 is an enigma...)

You decide to go to Gates Hall on your quest to find inspiration. Maybe moving
around objects inside will move you to write brilliant code. It's worth a shot,
anyway.

Type START to begin, and don't forget to check your inventory!

You're right outside the main entrance of Gates Hall. You're wondering why
you're standing out here when you could go INSIDE through the two sets of glass
double doors to the lobby.

Alternatively, you could head DOWN to the ground floor entrance.

You're standing in the middle of the Gates Hall lobby. You smell the aroma of
coffee wafting from the SOUTH where Gimme! Coffee is. To the EAST is a corridor
that leads further into the building, and to the NORTHEAST is the dean's office.

You can also go UP or DOWN the stairs, as well as go into the ELEVATOR. Or you
could head back OUTSIDE.

Dean Morrisett appears to be out of office right now, so you find yourself in
an empty office. Well, it would be empty, anyway, if it weren't for a single cow
making its presence known by mooing in the center of the office.

It's not every day you get to have one-on-one time with such a majestic
creature, so you decide to make the best of this opportunity by spending quality
time with the cow. Once you're done, feel free to go back SOUTHWEST to the
lobby.

The scent of coffee in the air leads you to the counter of Gimme! Coffee.
You wonder if the ability to write good code is directly proportional to
caffeine intake.

After you're done here, you can head back NORTH to the lobby.

MMMMMMMMMMMMMMD+?ZO:ZII8ZZ8$ZO$Z7OO88887888888O7$$OZZDZZ8IIO$O7+?NMMMMMMMMMMMMMM

You're walking along the first floor of Gates. To the WEST lies the lobby, to
the SOUTH you see the student services offices behind the glass wall, and to the
NORTH you notice the mailroom. Further along are stairs to go UP or DOWN.

exits.room: Far End of Gates, Ground Floor

rooms.description:
This is the faculty mailroom. There doesn't seem to be anyone here. Maybe you
could swipe something...?

(DISCLAIMER: Don't do this in real life!)

Feel free to head back SOUTH to the corridor.

You're in the student services area, which is the place to be for all questions
about degree requirements for CS or IS, student employment, affiliation and the
like! Unfortunately, it's not the best place for questions about programming.

NORTH of you lies the corridor from which you came.

You're in the lobby on the ground floor of Gates. Viable exits include WEST to
lecture hall G01, NORTHEAST to a corridor, SOUTHEAST to another corridor, UP
to the main lobby, ELEVATOR to go into the elevator, and OUTSIDE to go, well,
outside.

This is the entrance to the ground floor of Gates. Two of your friends, Alice
and Bob, who are taking Cryptography, are chatting intensely nearby. You
overhear some of their conversation.

Alice asks, "PntfclKUXlY7N5VK1ujAvJGjUY+N/6Vw+QonYKlfIYpTPB9K5yuihk96wtFzzSP1",
to which Bob responds, "ouSViRqbHkc0P280UAmY/m1c80Ps5Xu84VhfdL3hwS+fWD2TuWdQvhH
P5YMmrSj8i/jXE2xqXBrCpYkj2boZKA=="

Well, that was a waste of time. Too bad you don't have access to the secret key
they're using. You start to wonder if your name is Eve.

Anyway, maybe you should head UP the stairs to the other entrance or INSIDE the
building.

It seems as though you're interrupting a lecture. All the students look in your
direction and the professor asks you if you're lost. Your face turns bright red
as you relive painfully embarrassing memories from freshman year.

Maybe you should back out quickly toward the EAST before this situation reaches
unprecedented levels of awkward.

Something strikes you as odd about this corridor. While taking a pause to
comtemplate why, you realize that the door to the restroom is mysteriously
missing! You begin to reason about the situation like a software developer:

When it comes to other people using restrooms, you feel that the abstraction of
"walk in, walk out" is enough to explain what's been done. You don't need to
know all the exact details about what people do inside and how they do it
(though you hope that their hands being washed is a postcondition upon
exiting!).

However, since there's no door, now you can see all the implementation details
of the "use restroom" procedure. If only there were a way for you to hide the
implementation details behind an interface...

There's not much to do here besides heading NORTHWEST where you came from.

This corridor is a familiar one for many undergraduate students. You see the
tutoring rooms to your NORTH, the undergrad lounge to your SOUTH, more of the
corridor to your EAST, and the lobby to your SOUTHWEST.

exits.room: Further Down North Corridor, Ground Floor

rooms.description:
You were hoping to get some inspiration from the amazing TAs and consultants for
3110, but instead you've stumbled into office hours for another class. On the
whiteboard, "CS 1110" is written in bold letters. Below it, you see the
following:

"...A category whose objects are the object of C and whose morphisms from C1
to C2 are the C-morphisms from C1 to M(C2). Given f : C1 → C2 and g : C2 → C3
in Eff(M), their composition in Eff(M) is the C-morphism f ; M(g) ; µ_C3."

They sure teach some advanced material in 1110 these days.

You recall that 3110 office hours are being held in Surge Academic Building A,
Room 106, in the Ag Quad. Maaaaaaan. Better walk SOUTH back out then.

You see your 3110 classmate, Gary, sitting nearby in the undergrad lounge.

"Hey," you say, as you walk toward him, "have you started A2 yet?"

He responds, "Yeah right. I was just going to go to office hours on Thursday
when it's due and do the whole thing there. It's just 3110, man. What's the big
deal?"

Your heart sinks, and you quickly back NORTH away from Gary.

"All right, smell ya later," he calls.

rooms.id: Further Down North Corridor, Ground Floor
rooms.description:
The server rooms are right in front of you, but there's no obvious way to get
in. Other paths are WEST toward the lobby, SOUTH to the CSUG lab, and SOUTHEAST
to the far end of the corridor.

exits.room: Far End of Gates, Ground Floor

rooms.description:
Using your skills as a 1337 hax0r, you make it through the locked doors into
the server room. As you stare at the blinking lights on the server racks, a
message flashes in your mind: "AES-128 base64 ilove3110".

Obvious exits are DENNIS and XYZZY.

exits.room: Further Down North Corridor, Ground Floor

rooms.description:
You arrive at Dennis. He wears a sporty frock coat and a long jimberjam. He
paces about nervously.

You engage Dennis in leisurely discussion. You learn that his jimberjam was
purchased on sale at a discount market and that he enjoys pacing about
nervously. You become bored and begin thinking about 3110.

Obvious exits are NOT_DENNIS.

This is the place where the brightest young computer scientists turn coffee and
ramen into code! The symphony of click-clacks floods your ears as you walk to
one of glass rooms where you see your friend Xavier working.

"Hey dude," Xavier looks up at you with reddish eyes, "I stayed up all night
yesterday working on my formally verified C compiler. You'd think it'd be easy,
but it's not as simple as it sounds."

You pretend to agree and offer to get him some tea.

"Thanks man. Just drop it here when you get the chance."

You can go out NORTH to the corridor or EAST to the far end of the building.

exits.room: Further Down North Corridor, Ground Floor
Far End of Gates, Ground Floor

rooms.id: Far End of Gates, Ground Floor
rooms.description:
You're in the easternmost end of the corridor. There's a vending machine
sitting nearby where you can purchase "healthy" snacks at a "modest" price.
Possible exits are NORTHWEST to the rest of the corridor, WEST into the computer
lab, or UP through the stairs.

exits.room: Further Down North Corridor, Ground Floor

rooms.description:
You're in front of the ELEVATOR, and you can also go UP or DOWN the stairs. Also
to the SOUTHEAST is a corridor. The other areas on the 2nd floor aren't much
help on your quest to achieve 3110 enlightenment, unfortunately.

You're walking along the second floor of Gates. You see your friends Roger and
Robin sitting at a table nearby. It seems like they're working some kind of
project.

"Hey guys," you greet, "what are you working on?"

"Oh, just researching a new type inference algorithm," responds Roger.

Robin chimes in, "Yeah, it'll be a great addition for the programming language
I'm designing."

You have some really smart friends.

"We've been working on this for hours and haven't had any food yet though," adds
Roger, "You got any food on you? We'll pay you back."

Maybe you should go find them some food. Hopefully they'll put you as the 12th
author on their inevitably successful research paper if you do.

To the NORTHWEST lie the stairs and elevator, and to the NORTH is the homework
handback room.

This is where you pick up graded homework and exams. You haven't taken a 3110
prelim yet though (but you can't wait!).

Head SOUTH to exit the room.

"You have succeeded, my child," the great Zardoz bellows, "I shall bestow upon
you the greatest knowledge of all: the lambda. May you use it well."

You see a bright LIGHT in the distance that you can float toward. Before you
follow it, however, make sure not to leave anything important behind!

There's not much related to 3110 in the north side of this floor, but you do see
Prof. Constable's office to the SOUTH and a lounge area to the SOUTHWEST.

Alternatively, you can go UP or DOWN the stairs or into the ELEVATOR.

His door was open, so you walked in, but it doesn't seem like Prof. Constable's
in right now. As you linger in his office, you begin to daydream about dependent
types.

Exit NORTH when you're done here.

There's a nice open space here for students to work and relax. You sit down in
an open seat, and you notice that the person next to you is writing OCaml code.

"Hey, are you in 3110?" you inquire.

"Yeah," he replies, "I'm trying to finish up A1. By the way, do you know how to
plus two strings to make one big string in OCaml?"

You haven't got to heart to tell him that the hard deadline for A1 has already
passed.

"Oh, just use the caret instead of the plus," you respond.

He nods graciously and goes back to purely coding in utop.

Perhaps there are other ways to help the poor guy out.

You can go NORTHEAST from here to head back toward the elevator and stairs.

You are encased in metal. Possible exits include GROUND, 1ST, 2ND, 3RD, and 4TH.
You should make a decision quickly before you succumb to claustrophobia.

You find yourself floating in nothingness. What just happened...?

After taking a moment to come to your senses, you see a giant stone head
floating before you. That's right--you called out for Zardoz and he hath come.
He demands that you identify the following images and promises you great rewards
if you do so successfully.

After verifying that there's no way out of this situation, you agree to his
terms. Type START to begin...

You recognize a fellow 3110 classmate who's sitting at a table typing on her
computer.

"Arrgh, I shouldn't be using a loop here but I can't think of any other way,"
she grumbles.

Perhaps you could suggest an idea to her somehow...

As usual, you can go into the ELEVATOR or DOWN the stairs. There are also
corridors to your WEST, NORTHEAST, and SOUTHEAST.

You see the portraits of all the Computer Science Department Chairs, past and
present, lined up on the wall. You take a moment to bask in their presence and
hope that you'll pick up some of their wisdom by osmosis.

Head back EAST when you feel like you've absorbed enough wisdom.

There's a student here who seems a little out of place. He approaches you with
a look of curiosity in his eyes, and says, "Excuse me, is this Kennedy Hall?"

You kindly explain to him that he's in Gates Hall.

"Oh, that explains why I didn't understand anything in the lecture I went to,"
he mutters, "It seems I've lost my backpack too. Do you know where I can find
one of those?"

His lack of concern worries you, and you decide to leave the spaced-out boy
alone before you catch whatever he's afflicted with. Duck into Prof. George's
office to the NORTH or leave immediately toward the SOUTHWEST or the SOUTHEAST.

You see Prof. George helping students with CS 2800 material. For some reason,
you can't remember whether you're taking 2800 now or whether you've already
taken it, but considering that it's a corequisite for 3110, it couldn't hurt to
listen in.

They seem to be discussing the undecidability of the halting problem. Once Prof.
George finishes his explanation, he asks, "Can anyone name another undecidable
problem?"

Your hand shoots up into the air before you can think. Prof. George looks in
your direction, but before he can even call on you, you blurt out, "Has anyone
really been far even as decided to use even go want to do look more like?"

Silence fills the room. You're not sure what made you think saying that was a
good idea. Then, laughter ensues.

"Um, yes, I suppose that is undecidable, in its own way," Prof. George chuckles,
"That's not quite what I had in mind though."

You feel like this would be a good time to bow and gracefully exit stage SOUTH.

You see an angry student stomping her feet in front of Prof. Gries's door.

"What's the matter?" you inquire.

"Grr, I got an A in 2110," she fumes, "but I deserve an A+!! I swear my final
was graded wrong! I got every problem correct!"

"Do you have the exam on you?"

"Um, no, but I aced that exam! For sure! 100%!" she growls back.

You think it'd be best to let her seethe in peace. To the EAST is Prof.
Clarkson's office, and to the NORTHWEST and SOUTHWEST are other corridors.

Brimming with 3110 curiosity, you glide into Prof. Clarkson's office. He
welcomes you warmly and offers you a seat. As you sit, you notice a sign that
says "Think" toward your right, so you ruminate on what question to ask him.
After what seems to be an eternity of silence, you home in on the perfect
question: "Why do you love functional programming?"

Prof. Clarkson smiles, takes a deep breath, and starts: "That's a great
question! To answer that, we'll have to go all the way back to the beginning.
In the 1930's, Alonzo Church formulated what we now know as untyped lambda
calculus..."

As you absorb all this information, you feel as if spacetime is distorting
around you and this office.

"...so that's why functional programming is so great," Prof. Clarkson concludes.
You can't shake the feeling that you've been transported through a wormhole
somehow, but you definitely feel wiser and closer to enlightenment.

After you've confirmed that you're still on the same plane of existence as you
were before you walked in, head WEST to exit the office.

"Hey, are you awake?" you hear a voice say, "You should really be sleeping
somewhere more comfortable than my office, you know. I don't even have a couch
here, unlike some other professors."

You rub your eyes and sit up straight. Prof. Clarkson is looking at you with
concern in his eyes. Looks like you fell asleep somehow. "Sorry," you yawn in
response.

"It's okay, I just wanted to make sure you were fine. I know that 3110 takes a
lot out of you guys."

You nod groggily. Your bag feels a little bit heavier and your brain feels a
little bit brighter. "You've given me a lot of ideas to think about," you tell
him, "Thanks."

Prof. Clarkson flashes a smile at you and then swivels back to his computer.
Take a minute to process everything you've experienced and then head out through
the door toward the WEST.

(WARNING: Because this is a special event, dropping items right now is not
recommended! Reenter this office if you need to.)

You can visit the offices of Profs. MYERS, KOZEN, and FOSTER from here. Other
exits include NORTHWEST and NORTHEAST.

You wander into Prof. Myers's office. He greets you as you walk in, and he asks
if there's anything you need. When you respond that you're just here to chat,
he nods knowingly and discusses trustworthy software systems with you for a
little while.

As your conversation comes to a close, Prof. Myers reminds you to defend the
abstraction barrier, and you, of course, acquiesce.

You should exit his office through the door to the NORTH, since trying to exit
any other way would make you look a bit foolish.

You knock on Prof. Kozen's door. You hear a pleasant "Come in" in response, so
you enter his office. He seems to be poring over some books, deep in thought.

He looks up at you and asks, "What can I help you with?"

It is at this point when you realize that you're not taking Grad Algo this
semester and don't have any real reason to be here. You try to improvize a
response.

"Umm, I was wondering, err, what your favorite rock band--I mean, what you're
currently doing research on," you stammer.

His eyes light up as he engages you in a conversation about his research on
KATs (Kleene Algebra with Tests).

Once you've fully absorbed this information, you should exit his office to the
NORTH.

The door was ajar, so you slip into Prof. Foster's office. However, you somehow
missed the fact that there were voices coming from within, so you find yourself
interrupting a frenetic conversation between Prof. Foster and one of his grad
students.

"Would you mind coming back a little later?" he asks, while drawing a diagram
that strangely resembles a cat on his whiteboard.

You give them the most sincere "sorry" you can muster, as you prepare to
walk NORTH out the office.

You are somewhere that does not exist.

This "room" is used as a way to adjust the max points to win. Since some items
spawn in their treasure rooms, it's impossible to gain the points for those
treasures. Also, it enables a secret ending. (;

items.description: a bicycle whose safety and correctness has been formally verified in Coq
an engraving bearing the names of two professors
an interactive art piece that uses emotions as data and data as art
your ticket to a lesson in advanced programming languages
a piping hot cup of freshly brewed tea
a crescent-shaped pastry
an envelope addressed to a NetID (mrc26) instead of a real address
a completed form for affiliating to the CS major
a backpack lost by some poor sod
an illustration of many squares, each encased within the next
a bag of fried potato slices
a bar of chocolatey goodness
someone's CS 2110 final
the secret to functional programming
a framed photo of the CS Department Chair from 1993-99
a poster for the band, The Rebeckonings, formerly known as The Juliatrics and The Katatonics
an interface that protects clients from accessing the implementation
a swath of fabric used to make secure, open, distributed applications
a totally realistic simulation of soccer
a tangrams game with innovative drag and drop
the perfect coffee creamer
a computing machine of bovine origins
